comments.commentBody:
Take that haters!!!! In your face!

Let's go JETS!!!!! Bravo!
NBC had post football news, so biased against Jets. It has Gianst helmet on view display despite being loss for post season play-off.

Instead of starting playoff games in a scoreless tie, give 3 points to each team for every regular season win.  Then the decision to sacrifice a game to rest players would have a cost, and teams would have an incentive to win every game.

If the NFL allows the status quo to continue, the dictum of "On any given Sunday, any team in the NFL can beat any other team" will become meaningless.

No team should affect the standings of any team other than the one it is playing. For the Bengals to lose intentionally to the Jets (which they may have indeed done) to avoid having to play a much stronger team in week one of the playoffs is the same as throwing a game.

The strength of the NFL came on the shoulders of owners like Wellington Mara and Art Rooney, men who realized that in order to have a sport that flourished, every team would have to benefit, small city teams like Green Bay as well as big city teams like Chicago, all playing by the same rules.

With teams now taking dives late in the season, that sense of "alll for one and one for all" has vanished and fans will not long stand for it.

Once the integrity of the NFL is questioned, there will be a lessening of the six-month-long love affair millions of people have had with professional football.

The answer is not to award teams that have already clinched post-season positions with extra draft picks if they play their regulars. That would be counterproductive to the whole idea of the draft in the first place which was to give teams with poorer records an opportunity to advance through adroit draft picks.

Rather, a committee should determine that if a team doesn't care whether it wins or loses a late season game based on their use of available personnel, that team should then suffer a loss of placement in the following year's draft. There are questions of judgement that will arise, to be sure. The committee will have to be judicious and fair in setting up criteria for enforcement of the penalties.

But to do nothing will cause the NFL further concerns and risk greater alienation amongst its fans. This problem is bigger than just teams and players and even fans. It is a problem involving the future sense of integrity of the most successful American professional sports league ever established.

Even if your opponent has clinched and is allegedly mailing it in, your team still must execute its plan of attack. Against both the Colts and Bengals, the Jets have been focused and almost astoundingly effective in all elements of the game -- particularly on special teams, where lapses hurt them earlier in the season. A playoff team like the Bengals is supposed to be too good to suffer such a lopsided humiliation at this stage of the season, and certainly not be shut out in every way.

More importantly, the Bengals are in deeper free-fall than many folks are willing to admit. They just lost three out of their last four games, all to other playoff teams -- MIN, San Diego, and the Jets. Since week 11 they have managed wins over only Cleveland, Detroit, and KC. Whether the Jets backed in or not, Cincinatti appears to be in big trouble at the wrong time. Just look at Marvin Lewis' face tonight and say that this game was meaningless... He looked pretty upset and worried about what he was watching on the field.
Sometimes the easiest answer is the right one: US players, as well as US soccer in general, are not on the level of play of the best teams in Europe.

While it is true that there is racism with some fanatical elements in europe, I think that to attribute the lack of playing time for Adu to racism is a false notion. First of all Adu is playing in Portugal which was one of the first european countries to play african players in its national team..two mozambicans played for Portugal at the 1966 World cup and these two single handedly propelled Portugal to a semi-final spot. The number of Africans playing for top european clubs and teams in the all the leagues across Europe from portugal, england, France and indeed we have africans in Georgia, kazakistan, Armenia, Uzebekistan, Turkey to Finland etc etc...shows you that scouts are actively seeking african players and that race is a non factor.
The problem i see with Adu was the hype surrounding him at a young age. I think his skill is good enough; his stature is similar to Messi, and he is creative ( as seen at Canada 2007 under 20 World cup). The U.S national team is a team not known for creativity so to this end Adu will not find the light of day on a U.S team especially with Bob Bradley at the helm. I think Adu will rue the day he forfeited his chance to play for the country of birth; the black stars of Ghana. If someone had provided guidance to Adu, then he might have turned out to be the U.S version of Messi. It is much to do with the coaches tactics..and I think Adu is good enough to play for the US team if they know how to use him.

Kevin Kuranyi was born in Brazil to a German-Hungarian father and a Panamanian mother. He played youth football in Brazil, Panama and Germany. He has Brazilian, German and Panamanian citizenship. He was called up to the German U21 national team before being invited to the senior side later. This is not a case of fast-tracking citizenship. Not a single player for the German national team has ever been naturalized just so he could play for the German national team.

I don't think that Hull City is the best fit for Freddy. They are a defensive oriented team--though he would have his good buddy Jozy there to support him. I don't see much playing time if he goes to Hull. Aris is probably a smarter move and he would still have EJ to pal around with.

See my recent radio interview with Freddy here (faux?):

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0s8MDDZms8w

In my view the fault lies with the MLS . They have failed to bridge the gap between the level of competition in the US with the type of soccer being played at the club level overseas . The type of competition we see can be very weak at times . Too many games with meaningless outcomes .

The league should start to incorporate a system of promotion and relegation between the USL teams . Consolidate all the regional MLS divisions and make that the MLS Premier League . Compare with the European leagues where some of the most watchable soccer from this point forward will be at games where one or both of the teams playing are fighting off relegation . I'm sure it's not as simple as all that , but then , maybe it is.

This league set-up will instill a higher level of competitiveness in the players . Currently , once you get past the top 8-10 players in the league , it's doubtful that any of the rest would even make the first team squad of top league clubs elsewhere . Consequently , when the US players go overseas , they are fringe players at best , except for the top talent like Dempsey , Howard , Donovan , etc . The league has to start to diversify its ownership and start to pay young players comparable money to make it worthwhile for foreign players to play here . This market has the potential to be a "farm" league for the European leagues the way that Brazil and Argentina have become . I totally understand that it is difficult to make that comparison but we have to start somewhere . MLS players simply do not get top class competition week in , week out . Also , there needs to be more interaction with leagues in Mexico and South America where MLS teams might one day be invited to play in Copa tournaments .

Some might say pie in the sky and I know some of the hurdles that the league faces in trying to make any soccer league in the US a viable financial option , but they are falling behind badly , and we all know what happens when the rot sets in finally.

I guess the poster child for the failings of MLS players overseas unfortunately is Freddy Adu . Christened the "New Pele" when his made his MLS debut in 2004 at the hotly disputed age of 14 yrs old . He had a checkered rookie season with DC United and rumors suggested that even Manchester United were interested in signing him as a youth player . His appearances dwindled as issues about playing time surfaced with the coaching staff and Man Utd lost interest due to the ridiculous price that the MLS stuck on his head . Benfica eventually came in and signed him up but his appearances have been few and far between to the point where he was loaned out to first AS Monaco, and then Beleneses . Both of those two teams declined to buy him and sent him back to Benfica where he now wallows on their bench . A sad tale but a typical one.

It appears that the MLS is more concerned about image and appearance than it is about content and truly developing talent which is a shame because there is as much talent on the soccer fields of the US at ages 12-16 than anywhere else in the world . It's what happens afterwards that is cause for concern.

It's no good just naming your pro teams like the world famous clubs. You have to get them to play like them too.......................................

http://www.soccerlimeyinamerica>com

This may be peripheral and petty, but I think the photo accompanying the newspaper piece was a ridiculous selection.  It may capture part of the celebration after a critical goal in '02 (??), but it strikes me as a terribly un-athletic and unflattering pose of McBride and Reyna. It may mean nothing as we click online, but when I saw it in the paper, beside the flexing and dunking football and hoops stars, it didn't say much for soccer.  Times Editors: please use better soccer photos.
Our thoughts and prayers go out to his family.

We're in.
J-E-T-S!  All is forgiven.  I apologize.  These are not the same old Jets.
HAVING GROWN UP IN CINCY..... THIS IS JUST TYPICAL BE IT FOOTBALL OR BASEBALL; THEY CHOKED AS USUAL.  SO SAD TO SAY
cowher, cowher, cowher!!!
Okay, all you S(ame)O(ld)J(ets)F(ans), you know, all of you who moaned and groaned about Rex and Sanchez after every loss...? It's safe to jump back on the bandwagon again.

comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
It's hard to imagine Sheridan returning after the way his defense folded down the stretch here. One good showing against a poor Redskins team barely registers in his favor... and his handling of Umenyiora is questionable, to say the least. The players clearly aren't motivated and seemingly lack confidence in his schemes.

I believe that on his record Coughlin deserves to return... he made us a force again and so we as fans have gotten used to dominating, not just winning. Now that we're not even winning it is to fire up the chants for his dismissal, but I don't believe that that would be the proper course. That said, the collapse of this team falls squarely in his lap... he was never able to arrest the free fall of a team that beat up on the cupcakes, but then went 3-8 against everyone else. The only quality wins this season both occurred against Dallas, that's about it. It would be understandable if he were let go... as much as I wouldn't agree with it.

Certainly it seems time to blow up the roster on the defensive side of the ball.
This is a fabulous place. Even worth a drive from Phoenix.

Cliff Bells was once my favorite place in Detroit. I went there this evening to see the Mourning Voices perform. When I got there they were closing early. The new manager Pauly told me that they were having trouble paying their electric bill so the show was cancelled. I wont go back to Cliff Bells.

Some posters to this blog suggested during the past week that the Bengals had little incentive to win in their regular season finale against the Yets and that they might rest their starters.  Well, they rested their starters during the second half, but only after the Yets had thoroughly schooled the Bengals' first string, including #85.  I'm thinking that the Yets have the clear advantage next Saturday and that the Ravens have the advantage against the Pats on Sunday, which would allow Gang Green to go to SD the following weekend.  Green showed tonight that the running game is not a lost art, including the Mildcat with Brad Smith.  J! E! T! S!  JETS! JETS! JETS!
And then there's the alternative method of sinking the gondolier's pole into the muck at the bottom of the canal and tying off to it. This is, of course, the well-known moor of Venice.

First, let me apologize to the Jets defense for saying a few weeks ago that if they were ranked #1, it showed statistics lie. They're great.

Second, thanks to the Times for these blogs.

Go Jets!

My husband & I & 3 other friends all stayed at The Obeliks Hotel for a week in December long flights from NY we were all delighted with the hotel which is very cute, but also the fantastic location. We had the attic room & our friends had the family room. Our friends arrived a day ahead of us, but we all received a transfer from the airport (return also) as part of the deal which was great. nothing was too much trouble. The Hotel is in a fantastic location, only 5-10min walk to the Mosques & Topkapi Palace & about a 15min walk to the Grand Bazaar. There is a huge selection of restaurants only one street away which is another bonus. If you want to experience the Sultanahmet area we could not think of a better place to stay. The hotel terrace was great, both in the evening for a pre dinner drink with views of both of the Mosques all lit up & also in the morning for the terrific breakfast, with views out over the Marmara Sea & the Asian side of Istanbul. The rooms are not the biggest we have ever stayed in, but they were very comfortable & clean & the air conditioning was great which was important! If you don't like stairs then this hotel may not be for you - but if you like the idea of keeping fit while you are trying all the Turkish fare then you won't mind in the least! Value for money was exceptional - if you decide to give it a try we hope you like it as much as we did.shuttle service from Sabiha Airport. It's very expensive (60 euros) and the driver drove like crazy, typing messages on his cell-phone while doing 160 kph in the traffic, and shouting at the other cars that didn't open him the way. Some people may enjoy it though. We didn't.

On the way back, we took a normal shuttle service (appointed for us by the hotel staff), we paid 5 euro per person, the minibus of course stopped at few other hotels to take passengers, but the ride was

If you are planning the short trip to Nogales Mexico from Tucson  make sure to stop  off in Sonoita  and have  a meal  at Cafe Canela.. a  favourite of  Arizona Highways  magazine with a focus  on local food and wine..
